Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in computation, modeling, and digital collection have led to an exponential growth in the size of scientific data sets. This 'Big Data' is transforming the process of scientific discovery. However, many scientific workflows require that the data be transferred, via networks like the Internet, to an optimal location for analysis and collaboration. Unfortunately, scientists often encounter performance problems on these networks. To resolve these problems, researchers depend on the expertise of engineers at Network Operations Centers (NOCs) for diagnosis and resolution. Resolving these problems often requires a cycle of interactions between the user and engineer that can last for days if not weeks, seriously hindering the scientific workflow. This project, known as TestRig 2.0, will short circuit this cycle by deploying a simple, easy to use system that will automatically collect a wide variety of important network diagnostic information. TestRig 2.0 will distribute dynamically generated test environments that are tuned to the specific needs of NOC engineers. TestRig 2.0 will automatically runs a series of tests against the infrastructure, collect the results, and transfer them back to the NOC engineer. TestRig 2.0 will also conducted a coarse analysis of the collected data so as to give the engineers some initial insight into the collected metrics.

In this project, researchers at Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC) propose to build a system, TestRig 2.0, that will quickly and easily gather a wide range of important network diagnostic information. This system includes a centralized management server that dynamically creates and configures client optical disk image files (as defined by ISO 9660). This server will be at PSC; it will provide TestRig 2.0 services to multiple geographically diverse NOCs via a free subscription model. These bootable images will provide a known good TCP stack configuration and system environment. TestRig 2.0 will use this baseline environment to perform tests against the perfSONAR monitoring infrastructure and also collect other pertinent data. The resulting data will undergo an initial automated coarse analysis by the client in order to provide engineers initial insight into the data. The resulting analysis and raw data will then be packaged and transferred back to the appropriate NOC for analysis. The client ISO creation process will include a unique dynamically generated public/private key pair. This key pair will be used for the authentication of the client ISO, distribution management, and user/test management. The rapid collection of pertinent data will enhance the process of scientific discovery by allowing researchers to focus on their research, instead of running tests for network engineers. By providing a framework for the use and development of post-collection data analysis, the system will lower the bar required for effective network diagnostics across a wide range of support personnel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific workflows have become increasingly dependent on high performance wide area networking in order to complete necessary research using Big Data and remote resources. As such, addressing performance problems quickly is vital to keep the process of scientific discovery on track. Interaction between Network Operation Center (NOC) engineers and users frequently incurs significant delays due to the nature of email, inexperience on the part of the users, a lack of access on the part of the engineers, and a failure to request and/or inability to provide all necessary information in the initial exchange. During this period of time, which may extend over several days, the scientific workflow can be significantly slowed or brought to a halt. With this in mind researchers at Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC) developed a TestRig 2.0; a software suite that quickly and easily gathers a wide range of important diagostic information.  

The primary component of the TestRig 2.0 system is a dynamically generated bootable Linux ISO that places the user's system into a known good configuration and automatically runs a wide range of network tests.The results of these tests are then transferred back to network engineer assisting the user. Importantly, no changes are made the user's system as the Linux ISO run entirely in memory. The dynamic nature of the Linux ISO allows for each test run to be configured precisely to the needs of the individual user. This means that the specific tests run, the targets of the tests, authentication, and transfers take place without specific knowledge or intervention on the part of the user. 

The ISOs are generated by a management system run by the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center. This system allows organizations and network operations centers to sign up to generate these ISOs for their users. Provided as a free software-as-a-service this eliminates the need for organizations to manage this component directly significantly reducing barriers of entry for smaller institutions. 

TestRig 2.0 makes use of the publicly available perfSonar measurement infrastructure as targets for all network test runs. By using this system of more than 3000 test nodes TestRig 2.0 can provide accurate test results over both long and short network paths.

This system also make relatively novel use of cryptographic keys to provide a lightweight nonintrusive licensing like structure without the overhead of a traditional license. These cryptographic keys streamline the data collection process for both the user and the NOC while reducing security risks, software distribution overhead, and erroneous test runs. TestRig 2.0 also explores methods for the coarse analysis and diagnosis of the collected data. Reports generated by Testrig 2.0 provide engineers of all skill levels with useful entry points into the data, giving the engineers a better insight into the network environment.

In summary, TestRig 2.0 aids in the rapid resolution of network related performance bottlenecks in scientific workflows. This, in turn, enhances the process of scientific discovery by allowing researchers to focus on research instead of gathering network data for network engineers.
